title: Could a 20 mph speed limit become standard in our towns and cities?
text:
Drivers face the prospect of a 20mph limit becoming standard on inner-city roads as part of a blitz on dangerous driving.
New research shows that the majority of councils in England have lowered or are considering lowering the speed limit in residential areas.
Cambridge is one area that is considering introducing a city-wide 20 mph limit across the board.
In a survey, a fifth of local traffic authorities said they were introducing a widespread 20 mph speed limit. Credit: ITV News Anglia The report, issued by anti-speeding charity Brake, said of 122 responses from all 206 local traffic authorities, 21% said they had introduced or were planning to introduce a widespread limit of 20 mph.
And a further 36% had carried out limited trials.
"20mph limits are an effective and globally-recognised solution to unacceptably dangerous roads in our cities, towns, and villages. "Ultimately, we would like to see 20mph become the default urban speed limit in the UK."

Credit: ITV News Anglia A spokesman for the AA said they didn't oppose more 20mph speed limits but that if they are introduced the process should be managed in a sensible way.
He said: "Blanket 20mph zones extending onto local distributor roads risk diluting the benefits as driver frustration builds when the road environment becomes more suitable for through traffic rather than in distinctive residential shopping streets."
